title: Before 1 January 2021, who will be elected to be the next leader of Germany's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) party?
possible_answers: A new leader will not be elected before 1 January 2021
correct_answer: A new leader will not be elected before 1 January 2021
preds:
CDU convention in January. Delay due to covid.
https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/12/16/commentary/world-commentary/angela-merkel-germanys-next-leader/

It has now been confirmed that the party convention, which is the electing body, will take place online only in mid-January 2021. The election will then be confirmed by an additional mail-in election afterwards, so that the final result should be confirmed by  end of 22 January 2021. The winner of the digital election will then be the only candidate on the mail-in ballot, as all candidates confirmed they will withdraw from the mail-in election in case the do not win the first round. This question, however, resolves "A new leader will not be elected before 1 January 2021".
https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/cdu-grosse-mehrheit-im-praesidium-spricht-sich-fuer-digitalen-parteitag-aus-a-48dffb70-f544-434f-a6b9-2ff0d8787453

Röttgen überholt Laschet – Merz verliert an Zustimmung
https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article221162356/CDU-Vorsitz-Roettgen-ueberholt-Laschet-Merz-verliert-an-Zustimmung.html
> Im Ringen um den CDU-Vorsitz bleibt der frühere Fraktionschef Friedrich Merz mit einem Zustimmungswert von 27 Prozent vorn, allerdings mit einem deutlichen Verlust von acht Prozentpunkten. Verbessern kann sich Ex-Umweltminister Norbert Röttgen mit 16 Prozent (plus vier), während NRW-Ministerpräsident Armin Laschet auf 15 Prozent zurückfällt (minus neun).
https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article221162356/CDU-Vorsitz-Roettgen-ueberholt-Laschet-Merz-verliert-an-Zustimmung.html (!!!)

> Die scheidende CDU-Vorsitzende Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer hat den Bewerbern um ihre Nachfolge vorgeworfen, mit einem zerstörerischen Wettbewerb der Partei geschadet zu haben. „Die Partei hat bei dieser Diskussion gespürt, dass aus diesem fairen Rennen ein ruinöser Wettbewerb geworden ist. Und dieser ruinöse Wettbewerb fällt zuallererst auf die Kandidaten selbst zurück, aber auch auf die CDU“, sagte sie der „Augsburger Allgemeinen“. „Deshalb habe ich immer davor gewarnt.“
https://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/ruinoeser-wettbewerb-um-cdu-vorsitz-kramp-karrenbauer-ruegt-merz-laschet-und-roettgen-scharf/26646066.html Translation: CDU president Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer says she is saddened to see her grasp on power slip at last, but wishes well to the three candidates./s

possible game changer... Roettgen wants a "Zoom" election. In this FAZ interview he also says he wants to be Chancellor and CDU party boss. Here is link https://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/inland/roettgen-haelt-praesenzparteitag-der-cdu-fuer-ausgeschlossen-17053245.html
The election was postponed again in October 2020 and won't take place before 2021, the same year in which the federal election will be held for the renewal of the Bundestag.[3]

Junge Union für Friedrich Merz als CDU-Chef – Röttgen vor Laschet
https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article219241616/Junge-Union-fuer-Friedrich-Merz-als-CDU-Chef-Roettgen-vor-Laschet.html

AKK said there is no doubt the party meeting will not happen in 2020 yesterday, now *all* candidates conform, even Merz. Paul Zimiak, secretary general of the CDU, now confirms that all candidates agreed to probably hold the party meeting in mid-January, preferring an in-person meeting to all other options. However, a fully distanced, digital only meeting and voting becomes more likely, since either the German party law will be amended in that direction with the subsequent support of social democrat SPD now, or the existing law proves to be pandemic-proof with respect to judicial clarity with regards to online-only voting, as it is currently checked on behalf of the president of the German parliament, Wolfgang Schäuble. https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/kandidaten-um-cdu-vorsitz-einigen-sich-auf-parteitag-im-januar-a-0a6ff699-7872-40da-a7e6-b583cdd1a6cc

Personal post-mortem and an explanation for anyone, who would like to understand the decision to postpone the congress (no date mentioned, it purely depends on the development with Covid-19 and could theoretically even happen in 2020, if things got better): there are at least two theories about it, and both are plausible:
1) Merz claims, it was "huge parts of the party leadership, who wanted to prevent him from becoming party leader". True to a certain degree. Merkel and others wanted Laschet or Spahn, not him. Various reasons for that.
2) They knew, that a second (partial) lockdown was inevitable (it will start on monday), and you can´t stay credible when telling the population to have no contacts and yourself having meetings - no matter how small and secure they might be. A combination of the abovementioned reasons leads to the conclusion, that they didn´t want an "online only" congress, even if it had been possible. Should have combined them, but didn´t. I was totally wrong with this one. So much about living in the country and even having inside information... A little forecast: this question will re-emerge in a few weeks. They will have a bin for Spahn, and he will be 50%+ most of the time.
The lockdown could prolong what is becoming a political stalemate.  Impasse.  Patt (in German).
The for december 2020 planned meeting to elect a new CDU leader was postponed (very probably not until the next year)
Merz is manufacturing his own opposition. In German, link https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/merz-cdu-vorsitz-kommentar-1.5095327
10/26 - Covid strikes again and impacts another countries political plans.

https://www.zdf.de/nachrichten/heute-19-uhr/videos/cdu-parteitag-verschoben-100.html
No vote this year it seems because of the escalating 2nd Covid wave.

"Offen war nach Informationen der Deutschen Presse Agentur, ob es eine Verschiebung des Parteitags - der ursprünglich am 4. Dezember als Präsenzveranstaltung geplant war - ins nächste Jahr geben soll, oder ob es noch in diesem Jahr einen sogenannten hybriden Parteitag geben kann. Dabei würde an mehreren Standorten in Deutschland verteilt in Präsenz und virtuell gewählt . Als dritte Option galt eine Briefwahl." https://rp-online.de/politik/deutschland/cdu-parteitag-plaene-fuer-4-dezember-geaendert-steigende-corona-zahlen_aid-54237605
https://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2020-10/cdu-parteitag-coronavirus-absage The party's meeting in December, and therefore the election, has been postponed to next year.

Armin Laschet is now advocating a postponement of the CDU Leadership election in order to be a good role model to the German population when it comes to precautions against the pandemic (it is not known which role the fact plays that he is only second to Merz in a survey among 1,001 CDU party members (not electing delegates!))

They should have held their postponed 33rd Parteitag in August/September, which I expected.
Now it gets increasingly unlikely that a meeting in-person in Stuttgart in December will be allowed or possible. I wonder how they are going to react to the pandemic situation, and where they will relocate if Stuttgart will no longer be viable. Probably the CDU will have a meeting on the island of Sylt - most CDU members will own a second home, sponsored by intense lobbying contacts or well-paid sideline, there anyway...
No change; will see what the JU says.

Germany is not quite Japan, but "slowly building a majority among voting delegates" is code for "there is nobody else". There was a short window of opportunity this summer for the candidates to showcase their credentials, and Merz and Rottgen missed it. That window has now closed with 6000 daily Covid cases. I also think that there is still the odd chance of postponement in case of a public health emergency.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics-laschet-idUSKBN26Q0MK

Concerning Spahn: do voters like incredibility and opportunistic shifts? I don´t think so at all (and Spahn is clever enough to see that too of course). German left-wing media would totally focus on that, if Laschet drew back. Now they´re promoting Spahn, and if he got candidate, they would try to destroy him afterwards as "illoyal", "opportunistic" etc.. German media games only. If they quote minor opinions from less important CDU people, it´s for their own ideological reasons only. Staying on course. "Someone else" is not very realistic. This is about CDU party leader, not directly about chancellor candidate. This is about delegates and reelection. It´s about reality. It´s not about the world view of journalists.
It would surprise me if Spahn actually ran, but new articles make this a possibility. I think other people are over-updating.

There are reports that several CDU MPs of the German parliament ("Bundestagsabgeordnete"), among them some high-ranking with function in the party leadership ("CDU-Präsidium") are not contempt with the applicants to chose from, and thus encourage Jens Spahn (federal minister of public health, currently supporting the application of Armin Laschet) to apply for leadership himself.
It appears the race is much more open still than I assumed; maybe they're right in the middle of a party wing fight, and its time for kicks and knuckles. https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/jens-spahn-cdu-politiker-fordern-kanzler-kandidatur-a-00000000-0002-0001-0000-000173444506 (sorry, no article in English available to date...)

Reducing "no new leader" to zero because of the planned new law about electing party leaders online: https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/parteitage-coronavirus-union-parteivorstand-kanzlerkandidatur-1.5059143

All three candidates visited the party youth "Junge Union":
https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/laschet-merz-roettgen-101.html No more room for any other candidate, 1% "someone else" only for Laschet getting ill or dying and Spahn having to replace him.
They are absolutely determined to do the election. 1% "no new leader" for Covid-19.

Now this is going to be cute: " In Berlin, of all things, Bavaria’s Prime Minister Markus Söder (CSU) presents the biography of NRW Prime Minister Armin Laschet (CDU)." https://pledgetimes.com/faz-newsletter-an-exchange-of-blows-and-a-devastating-corona-balance/ Not only this, but also "Laschet is said he did not hesitate a second to agree to present a book of Söder's as well." So it seems the scriptwriting is done now, the roles are assigned: Laschet is going to be CDU leader with no ambitions to be a chancellor candidate of the Union/CDU, while he supports the candidacy of Markus Söder (CSU) who is a loudmouth in that respect anyway and would never give in before being assigned the most important role there is (Söder is a bad pretender...) Laschet is assigned for the quiet part, but being supported by Söder may be valuable for him in this phase.
There are a lot of issues on the plate right now that needed to worked an angle on in Bavaria's favor, such as the more than three decades old question which region in Germany will have the honor to be the haven for 1,000,000 years for all of Germany's nuclear waste (Lower Saxony already has it, other states think this founds a habitual right to leave it right there; Bavaria would be a good place to keep it, but, of course, they don't want it - despite having had 6 sizeable NPPs, two of which are still producing nuclear waste, and seven research reactors (two still active) on their grounds), and not least what will become of Bavarian industrial and automotive giants such as Siemens, BMW, Schaeffler Group, AUDI, and many more in times of economic crisis and of structural breaks catalyzed by the acuteness of the climate crisis.
Bavaria won't make it to the next decade without SUPER-MARKUS as a front line worker in Berlin
https://www.gameswirtschaft.de/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Froehlich-am-Freitag-2020-17-DCP-2020-Soeder.jpg
so Söder will finally admit before 15 December 2020 he is doing it, but only for "Bavaria's sake"...
Armin Laschet appears to be the appropriate counter-part for that. Merkel seems to be ok with that solution, as she has signaled before, even though this might not have been on her "wish-list". Whether or not the others will receive posts in a new government, depends on the coalition, and whether there will be another CDU/CSU led "Grand Coalition" which by numbers will not be that "grand" anymore, or a coalition with the Green party: Norbert Röttgen could play his part as Minister for Foreign Relations (AA), or for Environment Protection (BMU), while I cannot imagine - seriously - Merz being finance minister (BMF)  or minister for the economy (BMWi), or any minister at all.

Latest news from inside CDU: AKK and the three candidates had a meeting yesterday to discuss the "candidate process". They agreed to very specific dates for each of them (nobody mentioned anyone but those three, so no "someone else" in the game anymore; the media are still speculating about Spahn, but in AKK´s mail to the members there is no room for that option) when to speak online to the public (calendar weeks 46 and 48) and to the members only (calendar week 47).
So it´s basically down to Laschet vs. Merz.
According to german magazine "Spiegel" CDU members still favor Merz (see article below), but
a) it´s party delegates who wil vote, and they have their own agenda
b) the journalists at Spiegel hate Merz, but hope for him to became party leader to make it easier for their left-wing / green friends to get more votes next year. They will write, whatever it takes, to work on that - and then shoot him down big style afterwards.  If there are no major political changes or scandals till December, the general picture should be quite clear now. I´d say Laschet CDU leader, Söder Chancellor candidate, Merz, Röttgen and Spahn Ministers in the next Government. https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/friedrich-merz-liegt-beim-cdu-vorsitz-vorn-markus-soeder-in-k-frage-umfrage-a-0d3c07ff-c710-4354-8769-f8b3e14f70f3

A little more towards Laschet. Even among conservatives there are critics concerning Merz with much influence: https://www.focus.de/politik/deutschland/schwarzer-kanal/die-focus-kolumne-von-jan-fleischhauer-bei-jedem-auftritt-zeigt-sich-das-eigentliche-problem-des-friedrich-merz_id_12475015.html

Main argument for this shift towards Laschet: the delegates could fear Merz being perceived too polar. There could be voters, who wouldn´t have voted with any of the other candidates as CDU leader / Chancellor candidate, but to prevent Merz they might vote. And the mainly left wing/ green media in Germany will do anything they can, to make Merz look bad.  
The following article is excellent. Sorry, that it´s only availabe in German:  https://www.rnd.de/politik/leise-schleicht-sich-laschet-an-die-macht-steht-der-cdu-vorsitzende-schon-fest-HQE3UHI2OJBSTAFBJX73IZYZF4.html
Adjusting based on little new data.
Going up a little bit on Röttgen. Going down a little bit on Merz. Personally I think that the comment probably wins him general election votes from the AfD, though.

- Update: Merz using homosexuality and pedophilia in one sentence is getting him a lot of criticism. 
-> Lowering his chances a bit https://www.zeit.de/politik/deutschland/2020-09/homosexualitaet-friedrich-merz-aeusserung-kindesmissbrauch-kritik-bundeskanzler

Friedrich Merz is talking himself into trouble, it may be a trap by journalists, but the effect may be there anyway: Being asked if he had a problem with an openly gay German chancellor in an interview, he declined "No." But then he explained: "Sexuality to me is a private issue that is not meant to be discussed in public, as long as you comply to the laws and as long as children are not involved." It is a libertarian view, that is not wrong in itself. But most people who reacted to that statement, view it as an expression of Merz's alleged view that homosexuality has something illegal to it and may be connected or associated to paedophilia. It's certainly not what he said, but that's what is in the papers and magazines right now. Merz is known for having uttered more drastic homophobic "jokes" earlier in his career, e.g. concerning the then-mayor of Berlin, Klaus Wowereit. https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/friedrich-merz-jens-spahn-kritisiert-aussage-ueber-sexualitaet-von-politikern-a-c3aeaf9f-398c-49be-aeda-3950dfede05d
Late to the game. First forecast, mainly based on my media diet.

A little up for Röttgen, as attention shifts a little more from Covid-19 towards his area of expertise: foreign affairs. Down a little for "someone else", because Spahn really seems to stay part of Team Laschet.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

https://news.google.com/topics/CAAqIQgKIhtDQkFTRGdvSUwyMHZNR2RuTmpnU0FtUmxLQUFQAQ?hl=de&gl=DE&ceid=DE%3Ade I think that the campaigning period is advanced enough that I feel more comfortable making a prediction more untethered from the aggregate: Röttgen as a 1% rather than 5% "also ran", akin to Kayne in the US. Spahn to support Laschet, Söder to maybe go for Chancellor but not for CDU chief. AKK not to run. Laschet with a noninsignificant lead over Merz

Latest idea / rumors (from German magazine Focus) for a compromise: Laschet (if elected against Merz or Merz voluntarily gives it up) to become CDU party leader, the other candidates are promised nice posts in the next cabinet, too. Depending on opinion polls in December Söder or Spahn to become chancellor candidate, if Laschet´s popularity in the population doesn´t increase till then. That would not be a very attractive perspective for Laschet, but he is said to be determined to go for it anyway. Söder might indeed prefer staying in Bavaria (he´s been saying so for months now).
With Laschet and Merz both being VERY clear about wanting to be party leader, I´m now quite sure, that Spahn will not be it. Won´t change much in the bins for now, but it´s an interesting new perspective.

1) They seem to plan to hold it to elect a new party leader "whatever happens", so down a little for bin 5:
https://www.rtl.de/cms/cdu-parteitag-im-dezember-mit-bling-bling-gegen-corona-4613113.html
Very strict restrictions planned: measuring fever at the entrance, everybody has her/his specific place, etc. (the typical stuff). Interesting new one: everyone needs to wear technical devices that beeps, if two people come closer to each other than two metres. And they´re flexible about the exact locations (even football stadiums are being discussed). Looks realistic, that it can be done like that, even if the Covid-19 situation should get worse.
2) No sign for Spahn to change his mind to back up Laschet, so down again a little for bin 4. 
3) No apparent reason, why Röttgen´s chances should have changed.
4) Laschet and Merz with equally high probability: Laschet has most of the party leadership behind him and has just won local elections with in NRW, Merz has the sympathy of more of the party members. As the speeches of the candidates will play a big role, for whom the delegates vote, Merz could have a slight disadvantage: under Covid-19 conditions he might be less able to use his rhetoric brilliance to influence them.
Update: I have slightly increased Laschets chance of winning after the CDU showed good results in local elections in Northrine Westphalia, which will give critics less room for attacks

Soder (CSU) is seen as the most popular politician in Germany but being attacked by the left wing press (which may be a good thing).
Merz is more likely than Lanchet to offer himself as number two in a ticket with Soder.
Lanchet has lost popularity with the voters due his performance during the Covid-19 lockdown.
The Novichok/Navalny has raised the profile of Rottgen with conservatives by hardening Germany’s approach to Russia and could provide a good number two to Soder’s softer approach as a potential ticket.
It would appear that the CDU is looking to elect the best running mate for Soder as opposed to a Leader/Chancellor. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/sep/13/party-disputes-thwart-angela-merkels-hopes-of-an-orderly-succession

> An der CDU-Basis genießt Merz dagegen offenbar immer noch große Popularität. Diese braucht er im Kampf um den Parteivorsitz als Druckmittel, denn in den Spitzengremien, die formal zunächst gefragt sind, ist er nicht vertreten.

For a (German) overview of the candidates, see https://www.deutschlandfunk.de/cdu-wer-wird-neuer-parteivorsitzender.2897.de.html?dram:article_id=470100 - Laschet seems to have the largest backing from party officials
- He was, however, perceived as having done a poor job during the crisis and lost popularity in the public
- Merz already almost beat AKK in the last election and probably still has a good chance of winning. He seems to have good standing in the CDU basis
- Röttgen dies not seem to have much support and might drop out soon in exchange for a minister position
- Söder ist very popular at the moment. There has never been a CSU politician as head of CDU and it would be very surprising (less surprising would be his candidacy for chancellor) 
- I believe the prob of the election actually happening this year to be around 95%, since the CDU is under pressure to sort out their business, especially since the SPD has nominated Scholz.

No candidate seems to be favored by a majority, yet. 
Also the Bavarian (CSU) might still have a word in this. 
Although nobody favors the prospect, the candidate might only be elected as late as in the convention. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics-idUSKBN26129E
Hat-tip to @ThWedler for a lengthy description of the situation that illuminates the candidates and the issues.

I have tried to find something that adds a new angle on this question for some time, and have now found an article on the website of Badische Neueste Nachrichten that fits the bill (Badische Neueste Nachrichten, also known as BNN, is the only printed regional newspaper in the city and district of Karlsruhe). The article is incredibly chatty, but does give a few new insights:
- Laschet much more likely than I thought
- Virtual meeting unlikely if Covid returns
- "Someone else" probably a nonstarter by now if we conclude in 2020 at all
The translation is by Google Translate with a few manual adjustments made where Southern German dialect did not go through as expected. Who will succeed Kramp-Karrenbauer? The difficult search for a new boss for the CDU Angela Merkel retires as Federal Chancellor, Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer as CDU chairwoman. Three men apply for their successor. But do they also have the format for the candidacy for chancellor? There is growing nervousness within the party that, like two years ago, there could be a close result that does not satisfy the party. He is back. For months, Friedrich Merz was practically doomed to do nothing. In spring, the 64-year-old Sauerland wanted to travel through the republic and advertise at the CDU base from the Black Forest to Sylt for his candidacy for the CDU chairmanship. But then came the corona virus. First the special party conference planned for the end of April was canceled, then Merz even became infected with the virus and had to be quarantined at home.
The rulers are in the spotlight The public attention belonged to others. The rulers who have the power and the associated apparatus and are therefore in the public spotlight. In the face of the pandemic, his main competitor to succeed Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, the North Rhine-Westphalian Prime Minister Armin Laschet, was able to distinguish himself as a crisis manager, doer and caretaker with Health Minister Jens Spahn. At the same time, the Bavarian Prime Minister and CSU boss Markus Söder passed all CDU colleagues in the polls and positioned himself as the favorite for the Union's candidacy for chancellor. Merz, on the other hand, without an office or mandate in the CDU, stood on the edge of the stage and could only watch.
Merz shows his strengths as a speaker But the former Union parliamentary group leader is not thinking of giving up. There is still a lot of time until the election party conference at the beginning of December - and Merz is determined to use it for himself. He has recently been traveling through the country again and shows his strengths as a speaker at public appearances. In his view, the fact that he has neither a government position nor government experience is not a disadvantage. “I can operate machines,” he says confidently. He categorically rejects the demand of the Schleswig-Holstein Prime Minister Daniel Günther that the three candidates for the CDU chairmanship - Armin Laschet, Friedrich Merz and Norbert Röttgen - should get together and agree on a candidate for a "fight vote" to avoid the party congress. That would have a taste of "backroom dealing," he says. "We are not in the DDR (former East Germany)." Southwest CDU rejects the demand for a consensus candidate Criticism of Günther's approach also comes from the strong southwest CDU: "We have several strong candidates for the CDU party chairmanship and the candidacy for chancellor, all of whom have proven that they can take responsibility on the front line," says the influential CDU Group leader in the Stuttgart state parliament, Wolfgang Reinhart, opposite the BNN. "The other parties envy us this personnel situation." The timetable must be adhered to. The CDU now needs a clear order.
Wolfgang Reinhart, CDU parliamentary group leader in Stuttgart The head of the CDU North Baden, Minister of Agriculture Peter Hauk, blows in the same direction: "An election involves having a choice, that is the basic principle of democracy," he told our newspaper.
Peter Hauk rejects a virtual party conference The Southwest CDU firmly rejects the attempt by party friends to postpone the party congress and not elect the new party leader until next year. “The timetable must be adhered to,” says Reinhart. The elections would have to take place at the party congress in Stuttgart. "The CDU now needs a clear order." Hauk thinks nothing of a virtual party conference, as promoted by JU boss Tilman Kuban. To do this, the statutes must first be changed - and that can only happen at a regular party conference. “We have to hold the party congress in accordance with the corona. That demands concessions from everyone involved, but we will have to live with that. " A certain nervousness in the ranks of the Christian Democrats cannot be overlooked. After the SPD surprisingly proclaimed Vice Chancellor and Finance Minister Olaf Scholz as Chancellor candidate and FDP party leader Christian Lindner elected the purely Palatinate Economics Minister Volker Wissing as the new General Secretary, the CDU is concerned that the open and unresolved personnel issues will all the others by December Overlay topics. The outgoing chairwoman Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer is already warning of a "ruinous competition" between the three candidates. "We are not allowed to look around for four months while others have long since clarified their personnel issues" And here the link to the Sep 7th article:
https://bnn.de/nachrichten/politik/die-schwere-suche-nach-einem-neuen-chef-fuer-die-cdu
"Someone else" takes from Laschet, not from Merz.
It wasn´t complicated enough yet: rumors about Klöckner or Bouffier as possible compromise (and Günther again).

Articles only available in german, sorry. 
Key points:
- Laschet is very confident (my comment: means, that he is sure, Spahn will stay with him, so down a little for "someone else")
- AKK desperate, that there is no compromise in sight (my comment: they will most probably go against each other without making a deal, which means in the essence it´s Merz vs. Team Laschet in the end; no compromise also means: not Spahn, so down a little more for "someone else") Another comment: number of daily new cases in Germany´s "miniature second wave" ist going down again, so bin 5 getting a little less likely. https://www.merkur.de/politik/armin-laschet-cdu-spitze-kanzlerkandidatur-deutschland-markus-soeder-union-csu-zr-90034276.html?itm_source=intern-cia&itm_medium=listinarticle&itm_content=90033416&itm_campaign=merkur_politik_universalvsmostread&itm_term=1 https://www.merkur.de/politik/kramp-karrenbauer-zdf-sommerinterview-cdu-armin-laschet-friedrich-merz-norbert-roettgen-machtkampf-zr-90033416.html

A multimillionaire and former big time corporate lawyer Merz is  tall, mediagenic, outdoorsy, a pilot. Wife is a judge. One can say that he lost his first go round in the party leadership derby because he was bushwhacked by the politically correct who projected AKK to become the "next Merkel" and that she has disappointed on the charisma front, ultimately stepping down.  Merz as leader and dealmaker can bridge EU, German politics and German business and fill any prospective real or media-created power vacuum in the "post-Merkel" era.

We´re definitley down to Spahn as only potential "someone else". There´s no way for AKK or Günther to keep their credibility, if they decided to go for it themselves after what they said in the past few days.
Shifting again. 
Bins:
1: Candidate No. 1 for many.
2. Candidate No. 1 for many others.
3: Röttgen will be a minister under whomever they will elect.
4: He said several times, he wouldn´t try it, but he might be the compromise all others could agree to: Spahn (being very popular and conservative, but "not Merz" might really help).

Although I don't think it's impossible for practical reasons that the CDU will decide to leave everything as it was for the next two years, which would mean A K-K remains party leader and the answer may be 
"A new leader will not be elected"
on these grounds, two things are important to keep in mind, which point to A K-K in person, and in her current function. When leadership crisis in the party paved its way in January 2020, it was notable that, it was Merkel herself, who previously helped putting A K-K into that position for personal sympathy, maybe by the similarities in style of policy or their "friendship" (whatever this means in a political frame probably its A K-K's utmost support during the 2015 asylum crisis, and her eternal loyalty towards Merkel) over the years, and it was evenly and significantly Merkel herself (on a travel to African countries) who dismissed A K-K for weakness and disorder within the party, and a lack of leadership, so Merkel's support for A K-K seemed to be gone definitely and will not be easily restored.
Secondly, her dismissal had a reason: A K-K opted to retreat from that position, since she failed to recognize early that her party colleagues in the State of Thuringia were about to seriously damage the constitutional grounds on which the CDU has always seen itself standing, by secretly negotiating and brokering a ridiculous government coalition with the unconstitutional AfD "party", which is about to be on the watchlist of the German "Verfassungsschutz" service.
Her fail to foresee problems, to intervene powerfully and to avert a loss of credibility will stick to her, no matter what the next Bundesparteitag will bring and however the election of a party leader will go ahead.

Slight shifts. Very sorry, that this article is available only in German:
https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/cdu-parteispitze-kanzlerkandidatur-laschet-merz-roettgen-1.5001541 Süddeutsche Zeitung is one of the top "quality newspapers" in Germany, Most of them, especially SZ, tend to be politically left-wing, although the majority of the population is not, but they are very good. This article is a great analysis, not ideologically influenced. Good enough to change my forecast a little. Key points:

- Röttgen has got almost no chance, 
- Laschet needs to stay being candidate for party leadership to save face (my addition: if he does so, Spahn will most probably not go against him),
- Merz really, really goes for it (I seem to have underestimated his will so far, not understanding his real motives),
- no other candidate is mentioned (so down a little for Spahn, and forget about Braun, Günther or whomever else), but AKK might go for it again (so a little up for "another candidate" because of her) Other additions: 
- German media has already started to try and sabotage Söder as chancelor candidate, which increases probabilty of the CDU leader to be elected becoming chancelor instead of him (with current opinion polls the CDU/CSU candidate will clearly become chancelor next year, no matter with whom else in a coalition). 
- the party congress will take place. It will be shorter and smaller than usual, but it will take place, unless millions of black swans darken the sky above my homecountry. This question is as tricky as they can ever be, thanks again to Covid-19. Did I ever mention, that I really hate that creepy virus and its influence on everything?

Tobias Hans (CDU, Saarland MP) stated recently that planning for the December Parteitag is on schedule and that it will be executed however possible. He also stated once more, how important that congress will be for the party and its compliance with German party law, and that all options, including virtualization, are considered and precautions are being taken to make it happen. Negotiations for necessary changes in German party law (that currently prevent virtual congresses from being recognized as such) have started, so I exclude the option of another postponement or cancellation from now on.
Armin Laschet (CDU, Northrhine-Westphalia MP) was recently visited by Angela Merkel in his state, which was reminiscent of Merkel's visit to Markus Söder and his state government in mid-July. He showed her the remains of the industrial heritage of the Ruhrgebiet (e.g. Zeche Zollverein in the city of Essen) instead of baroque gilden castles, which may point to his intention to be more eligible to work class and middle class-people. First and foremost, it appears to show Merkel's support and approval for Laschet, however not exclusively for Laschet.
I still favor Röttgen for his deep knowledge and understanding of foreign policy, which seems crucial in this age of virulent, interwoven and complex conflicts, he'd also stand for continuity in one of Merkel's leitmotifs, "Ausgleich" (balance). However, there's a fine line to inactivity and hesitation he'd have to overcome.
I still can't imagine Friedrich Merz's successful comeback into politics - no way. I can't imagine Merkel showing her approval of his ahead of the Parteitag either, so there will be no visit to Friedrich Merz whatsoever - where should Merkel travel, to his private yacht in the Mediterranean? Where would they meet, in "Haus Sauvigny" in Brilon, where his old money family has been seated?
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haus_Sauvigny
In times like these, having no responsibility and thus no opportunity to prove one's capacity is a big handicap. The only way out for Merz is his close ties to all sorts of industrial lobby groups, which start to play and polarize between unions and employers, whine for subsidies, warn of bankruptcies, layoffs and a futures lack of vocational education spots or simply demand more taxpayers' money or outright tax cuts. They've done so at all times, in good and bad times, in boom and bust, so it wouldn't mean a thing - except more pressure on "green" regulation and other rational policies, all of which Friedrich Merz would happily deliver.

Günther is an interesting idea, that @SE_Meyer brought up for "someone else". I hadn´t thought about him at all so far, but he would really meet some criteria. I think, it´s too early for him, but he will definitely be on the shortlist for the future. No change in forecast for now, but learned something new.

Things don't go well for Markus Söder (CSU) and his aspiration becoming the next chancellor of Germany in the 2021 general election.
Things started well, when Bavaria announced it will arrange mobile testing stations for SARS-CoV-2 next to German main transit roads  towards the Southeast of European neighbor countries (Austria, Czech Republic mainly), so people can get tested safely and quickly when returning home from travel not only on the airports (MUC introduced airport testing sites very early), but also for people who enter Germany making their trip by car.
On 12 August 2020 it went public that 44,000 of the tests taken among car passengers, which resulted in 900 positive cases among residents across Germany, have not yet lead to any action according to guidelines (notification, quarantine, reporting,...) after days and weeks. About 100 further positive test results could not be assigned to the respective citizen or person tested. They obviously got missed out by public health administration somehow. https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/analyse-soeder-101.html Critics are furious, Söder's ability for chancellor and as a crisis manager has been called into question altogether, and he refused to dismiss the Bavarian minister for public health, Melanie Huml (CSU), for the time being, downplaying the incident as a glitch. One detail in the story makes me adjust my forecast to concentrate further on "Someone else", reducing every other bin: Söder had initially been scheduled to make a trip, which has been cancelled in the wake of the incident. The trip would have led to the land of Schleswig-Holstein and its capital city Kiel, where Söder would have been received by Daniel Günther (CDU), the current head of state in Schleswig-Holstein. If Merkel's trip to Herrenchiemsee castle with M. Söder is an early indicator for the CDU's approval of Söder's candidacy for chancellor, then Söder's planned trip to Kiel and meetings with Günther are probably a harbinger Günther may enter the race for party leadership of the CDU belatedly, since it would have meant a meeting of the future top personnel of the Union parties, and could have signaled unity and "Friede, Freude, Eierkuchen" as we say in German.
Now we'll have to wait and see what becomes of Söder's interim crisis: if it doesn't cause a major spike in cases above 2,000 per day in August, he'd be safe; but the idea that Söder will become candidate and Günther (CDU) will become party leader to represent the northern part of the country balancing for Bavaria could be clear-cut, in my opinion.

A little more for Merz. I so far had not included the public opinion in the eastern states enough. They (and their delegates) like Merz very much. Instead of voting AfD they might come back to CDU with Merz as the new party leader. Some of them are still in "GDR-mode" (voting for post-communist Die Linke (still the same party as former PDS, and SED (GDR communist rulers) before that)), but many others don´t want anything less than more left-wing politics. Merz would be a way out for them. What´s still not clear: Söder claims, he wants to stay in Bavaria and Spahn still claims, he will be number 2 for Laschet. Might be true, but I don´t believe it. A few months with opinion polls and Covid-19 to go, so let´s wait and see...

I gave it some more thought and changed my prediction. By now Söder looks likely to be the chancellor candidate for the Union. The pictures of Merkel "in the same boat" with him as well as the "queen and the crown prince" motifs speak for themselves.  If true, the future CDU leader won't be the chancellor candidate. Laschet wouldn't want to give up his chancellor candidacy, making him unnecessary trouble if elected party leader, besides his already numerous incompetent remarks.  Merz has surprisingly or not been disqualified by Schäuble, the most senior CDU member. There won't be an easy way around his dismissal and probably his instincts are right. Merz never took had position in the government, and it's not the time for a banker with no real political backgrouund.  This leaves us with Röttgen, who isn't too keen on being a chancellor. But there is somewhat still a fourth candidate, Jens Spahn. He would be a the most fitting, as he is a too young to be chancellor material and to some degree, as the sidekick of Röttgen, still in the game. For a couple of weeks, during the beginning of the pandemic he was the man of the hour. The most probable scenario seems to be: Laschet and Merz are out, Söder is the chancellor candidate, Spahn will come back from the Bench and gets to be the head of CDU, preparing him to be a future chancellor candidate and Röttgen gets to be President as a reward for his loyalty.

Soder's chances have hugely increased recently.

Merkel is on a visit to Bavaria right now and was invited, for the first time in the past 15 years, to take part in a session of the Bavarian state government. The pictures, or photo-ops, that are a likely reason for this vist https://www.sueddeutsche.de/image/sz.1.4966666/974x731?v=1594720582 are produced obviously to demonstrate M. Söder's "chancellorability", it will leave the impression that at least Merkel is somehow contempt with Söder as the future Union candidate for chancellor (cute, aren't they?). Söder, however has not yet made any remarks on any application, and used to play things down so far, but that is within the usual range of dynamics.
This implies that the CDU election likely in December 2020 is pre-empt by the fact of the matter, and will no longer be about the question, whether the future CDU party leader is also an apt candidate for chancellorship. It will come down to whether she or he will be able to integrate different mainstreams within the party, integrate and unify the party as a whole, be a good administrator with good connections to other party elite and a wide knowledge of party law, and not least lead the CDU in a successful as possible 2021 election campaign (without any dirt or misbehavior popping up in the meantime...). https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/merkel-soeder-herrenchiemsee-1.4966546

As Germany has the presidency of the EU until 31 December, and Merkel is, once again, seen as the least offensive option for leader in Germany, there is every possibility that some fudge might be found to keep a decision being made (public) until Spring 21.
It is also much more likely that a candidate who is not part of the "same-old" Berlin-centric mainstream will be chosen - quite probably Söder from Bayern.

The CDU poll reported in this seems the best start point https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-05/merkel-critic-leads-loyalist-in-cdu-race-according-to-poll . More recent polling (for Chancellor not CDU leader) also looks good for Merz and not for Laschet or Röttgen https://www.thelocal.de/20200710/is-bavarias-leader-on-course-to-become-germanys-next-chancellor The tricky question is Söder.  There's obviously strong incentive for him to throw his hat in for Chancellor; but would he do so as CDU or CSU leader?  I think this will be a wait-and-see question.  I think it's unlikely there'll be no leader going into 2021 given that's the year of the next election; also Germany seems pretty willing to unlock.  But I was wrong on them cancelling the Special Congress so...

@chiefthe
You were asking these questions earlier:
"A couple questions I have that you may be able to help with:
1. Is there any polling of voting party members for the leadership? Or is it mostly about reading the tea leaves and sensing which way the wind is blowing?
2. Soeder seemed to be saying, from the articles I read, "no" out of one side of his mouth, and "yes" out of the other for moving to national politics and out of Bavaria. Is that common behavior for Germany politicians? Or is Soeder particularly odd for keeping his options open?" I find these comments quite illuminating and comprehensive: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1069820 First, there are couple of gallup institutes in Germany which ask about sympathy for politicians, and in the past 20 years the political field has undergone much field research from a marketing perspective. Sentiments seem overwhelmingly important for political decisions, sometimes I get the impression the effect on voters from their doing is the only category in which politicians are able to think today. However, from my personal view I don't like sentiment-based politics, because it complicates rational decision-making, and frequently "necessities" are left out, even though they're basic, just because they're unpopular.
On the other hand, ownership of the gallup institutes makes them suspect to a biased view, and to trying to manipulate voters in a way (by making false claims), it is easy to get the desired result by design of the question. Then it is also questionable, whether some of the polls are representative, since the numbers of people asked are usually small and there's no disclosure about who (geographically, urban or rural, age groups...) is asked, and I doubt there is no bias to it, too, depending on the respective question and on who pays for the study.
However, there is the ZDF-Politbarometer, which is frequently cited, and which should be independent enough (as ZDF is viewer funded public TV channel), with a slight leaning towards conservatism. It has a monthly review of sentiment towards the ten "most important" politicians by the time, here's the June publication https://de.statista.com/statistik/daten/studie/1817/umfrage/noten-fuer-spitzenpolitiker/#professional You should know, there is some arbitrary decision in the question "who is important", since e.g. Lindner (FDP) has no function at all except being the party leader of a small opposition party, about which it is not certain they will clear the 5%-hurdle to become members of the next Bundestag at all. It seems a bit of a tradition that they are mentioned in this poll... On the other hand, there is Habeck (Green party), who has no function either at the moment, but who is the flagship of the Green party (~19%) and is likely to become their next candidate for chancellorship, if they decide to have one at all.
Merz isn't in it, because he is not a politician at all at the moment, which I support, but his potential importance due to our overall question as above, he should be polled somehow, too. Then there's the phenomenon that usually the chancellor and finance minister (who is vice-chancellor at the same time by tradition) are rated best, but I suspect this is only due to folks who aren't exposed to politics or aren't really interested in respond like that just because it is the few names they recognize at all. Publicity makes popularity (that's why all ambitious politicians fear nothing more than not being in the news somehow).
It is a rare picture that most top ten politicians have a positive overall sentiment (maybe due to crisis management in the pandemic) except Lindner, who has the fame of being a snooty-nosed little upstart.
If you trust ZDF-Politbarometer, then Söder will become the next candidate for the Union, and also will become chancellor. The SPD is likely not to announce a head candidate at all, since it would be unrealistic to think about their chancellorship at all with their current polls (14 to15%) in mind. But maybe, in times of wonder, the German population will realize how large a share in their current well-being the SPD has, and polls will change, I don't know. That is why these polls tend to be a narrative or a constructed reality, imho, as long as there is not a real voting situation.
There may also be polls about this special issue of CDU leadership, but there is none that I know or can recommend right now; it may be more visible in the news the closer we get to the actual voting "Parteitag", which seems to be in Stuttgart in December as of today. Here's a platform for German topics with embedded surveys on other media, which seems to be interesting and which I discovered just today. However, there's no guarantee they're impartial or unbiased: https://civey.com/ "BILD", which is not even considered a newspaper, but is part of the rainbow press due to their mass of large scale pictures, headlines and advertisements, used to be a good indicator for the general sentiment of the working class for decades, but I think their influence and feedback into the political process abates, since they're losing their traditional readers and thus their scope. Second, I think this odd-seeming, almost schizophrenic behavior is typical for the election process of a German chancellor. If you take e.g. Gerhardt Schröder, who has been chancellor twice, was a rather low light, but ambitious enough to apply for candidacy for chancellor of his party SPD. He used to have a good support in his state of Lower Saxony, but only shortly ahead of the general election, he became powerful enough within his party, after (with support of the industry in his state; there is a lot of steel works and car manufacturing, e.g. Volkswagen in Wolfsburg) he took out a large one-page ad in each and every newspaper in Lower Saxony with the slogan ""Der nächste Bundeskanzler muss ein Niedersachse sein!" (The next chancellor must be a Lower Saxonian!) The slogan caught attention, since inhabitants there were implicitly promised to be granted advantages if "one of them" is ruling. As a result, he was winning big on his state level, became the SPD's candidate, and finally won the general elections by a slight margin.
I think that's what Söder is aiming at, too: all his signals and rhetoric are pointing to making the Bavarians believe he was only interested and focused on promoting Bavaria to create the impression of a strong support of his grateful home population on the state level, which then renders possible his candidacy for chancellor in the first place. By voting for CSU on the state or municiple level to make Söder stay in place, Bavarian voters will actually vote him to Berlin. Don't worry, that's the normal craze of German politics. Timing seems to be everything in this game: you will have to appear to be pushed by your believers into more ambitious positions, otherwise you will appear poor and desperate.
If you announce your will for candidacy too early, media will find some dirt to throw at you, and you will be burnt early. Even whitin a politician's individual careers, there's a "right-place-right-time"-aspect to it. Schröder served under the party leadership of Rudolf Scharping, who had a general perception of being slow, "sleepy", and unambitious. In the light of this, Schröder had to appear to be the better alternative by fate, after Scharping lost a general election. In other surroundings, Schröder would have been just one of the many.
Some talented politicians or technocrats have not understood these mechanics of popularity, and were ambitious at the wrong time, and failed or remained one of the many just the same. Who will ever remember Thorsten Schäfer-Gümbel? He's not so much different from CDU's Daniel Günther of Schleswig-Holstein, just on the other side of the popularity hill...
Günther seems to be one of the unknowns in this process, by the way, i guess we will hear more of him some time. By the way, Friedrich Merz just recently uttered misgivings and is not sure yet, whether he will support a proposal for a quota for women in top party positions, which will be elaborated in further detail before it will be voted on on the December Parteitag. That makes him appear less eligible for party leader at least for one half of the population...

As Covid-19 is now unlikely to "disappear" this summer and we are likely to have a severe 2nd wave in winter 20/21, a postponement from December to 2021 of the vote is quite possible. "Someone else" is not really German style. My money still on Merz for the nomination though, regardless of timing.

Armin Lachet has the Federal Minister of Health as his running mate [1], but has been chastised for making not-so-nice comments about immigrants [5]. Merz is "well known for seeking to reduce complex issues to the simplest of terms" and seeks to have immigrants conform to liberal German values [2]. He lost the leadership vote by about 10% in 2018 [2].  In a recent poll, Soeder, the Bavarian State Premier, ranks first at 65%, but is ambiguous about if he will run, seeming to want to stay put in Bavaria; Merz trails at 16% [3]. Roettgen in February  was "not widely seen as a big hitter in the party and few political analysts rate his chances" [4]. Campaigning is likely not to begin until the fall, due to COVID [3]. It seems unlikely that the CDU/CSU will delay this a second time. It seems like the big question is regarding Soeder and if he affirm a desire to run. I am going to be more toward that, with the alternative that Merz's penchant for simplicity will prevail over the remaining likely candidates. [1] https://carnegieeurope.eu/2020/05/29/beyond-european-crisis-management-germany-needs-post-coronavirus-vision-pub-81991
[2] https://www.dw.com/en/friedrich-merz-the-merkel-critic-eyeing-germanys-top-post/a-52331683
[3] https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/strong-public-support-for-cducsu-but-questions-remain-on-merkels-successor/

An excellent informative dialog from other forecasters who have skin in the game, thank you for insights. Now how to assign probablities on what appears to be a wide open contest. Das ewige wiederkehr des gleichen...   Perhaps the best adjectives in German to describe the candidates mentioned are... schlappheit... lustlosigkeit... and add AKK to the mix as another of the "unzufriedenstellend."   Even Rainer Barzel, the CDU "patzer" from the old Willy Brandt days would be better than these names...  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainer_Barzel

@SE_Meyer has a very good summary of the recent history of the CDU leadership race, that I largely agree with. However there are two questions following from his/her list of weaknesses of the candidates (and I agree at least Merz and Laschet would lead to significant losses for the CDU, if not immediately then through their sheer incompetence):
- Who will be elected by the party officials (which most likely don't agree with our analysis)?
- If none of the current candidates are deemed competent enough: Who else will seek and take the leadership role? I really do hope that we won't elevate Laschet or Merz. The former showing his lack of competence on a near-daily basis with more or less idiotic suggestions how we could restart the largest congregations of people (Bundesligaspiele), while completely ignoring the normal economic problems, where his focus as a state leader should lie. Especially with him being part of the (at least self-proclaimed) "economically more literate" party. And Merz shows time and again that he is neither willing nor able to contribute anything unless he is the undisputed leader and he has a large black mark against him with his BlackRock history. I'm always vary about outsiders as they allow far too much projection space for the abstract hopes of the people (see also the crash and burn of Martin Schulz 2 years ago) and then if elected lack the appropriate contacts and networks to actually affect stuff.
There is some argument to be made for Norbert Roettgen, I'm somewhat sceptical, due to his history of conflicts with Merkel, I do think there is a significant risk of Jens Spahn becoming the new party chief though.  Therefore I'm going to hedge a bit: It is unlikely for the party leadership to stay as is, in particular as AKK already said she won't be leading the party, there may be delays to that, but due to the next election being next year, I do think the CDU would be well advised to decide their leadership this year (5%). Both Laschet and Merz have significant backing and won't go quietly. I do think especially by the good performance of the current government (it turns out it's actually helpful for the chancellor to have some science background), both Merz (as the primarily Merkel-is-wrong-candidate) and Laschet (due to his both ineffective and contra productive attempts to trigger some "reopen earlier" campaign) lost appeal, I'm still giving them 15% each due to Laschet being the leader of the largest state organisation of the CDU and Merz due to his (in my eyes inappropriate) outsider appeal. These options cover a third of the probability: Roettgen is a complete wildcard (too little visibility in the greater public) but he has not actively degraded the argument for him in the past month or so. I'm giving him 20%. The rest  (45%) therefore goes to someone else. Side remark: The current "corruption" scandal that is blowing up around Augustus Intelligence, Philip Amtor and other prominent CDU party members (Guttenberg, Maasen) may develop a significant impact. Iirc there was some connection between Merz and Guttenberg, so things may become interesting from that direction too

This is a decision about the future path of the CDU. A move to the right, or more of the status quo. Rottgen has a significantly lower chance of becoming the leader at this stage. Merz very narrowly lost to Kramp-Karrenbauer in 2018. And is polling as the favourite amongst CDU supporters and the wider population.[1] Laschet’s chances increased following Spahn's backing. His approval ratings have increased during the COVID-19 crisis. But still seems to be lagging behind Metz. There is a chance of cancellation due to the pandemic. However, there will likely be a period of time when a decision can be made before 1 Jan 2021. It has already been cancelled twice.  Criticism is very welcome! https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-05/merkel-critic-leads-loyalist-in-cdu-race-according-to-poll
